Fig. 1 TEM images of fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst：(a) TEM images and particle size distribution of fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst; (b) HRTEM diagram of fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst; (c) TEM image and particle size distribution of spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst; (d) HRTEM diagram of spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst and corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) of the selected area. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XPS study of the fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts：(a) Co 2p spectra with red lines corresponding to Co3+ and blue lines corresponding to Co2+; (b) Ag 3d spectra with red lines corresponding to Ag0 and blue lines corresponding to Ag+; (c) O 1 s spectra with O2 line corresponding to O in vicinity of oxygen vacancies (Ov); Co3O4-H2 was a partly reduced Co3O4 by H2 at 350 °C. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of Co2.0/SiO2, Ag0.5/SiO2, fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2–TPR analysis results of Co2.0/SiO2, Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 and Ag0.5/SiO2. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NH3–TPD profiles of the different catalysts and SiO2 support for reference. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Schematic of the as-fabricated components of the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst and the catalytic functions. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of CoAg/SiO2 catalysts with different Ag and Co loadings: (a) with different Ag loading; (b) with different Co loadings. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XRD patterns of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts at different calcination temperature. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effects of temperature (a), time (b), and H2 pressure (c) on the HDO of syringol over Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2. Reaction conditions: 500 mg of syringol in 10 mL of n-dodecane, catalyst loading = 50 mg; other conditions: (a) 3.0 MPa H2, 2 h; (b) 260 ℃, 3.0 MPa H2; (c) 260 °C, 2 h. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Reuse of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 in the HDO of syringol. Reaction conditions: 500 mg of syringol in 10 mL of n-dodecane, 260 °C, 3.0 MPa H2, 2 h. In situ activated CoAg bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrodeoxygenation of syringol to cyclohexanol Chunyu Liu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a Jingbo Mao Writing – review & editing Validation Methodology a b ⁎ Hui Lv Validation a Jinxia Zhou Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Conceptualization a b ⁎ a College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University Dalian 116622 China College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian, 116622, China b Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals, Dalian 116622, China Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals Dalian 116622 China Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals, Dalian, 116622, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China. College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University Dalian 116622 China Development of highly effective catalysts for selective hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of syringol, a model compound of lignin, to cyclohexanol (CYHAOL) is a challenge due to the intricate molecular structure of syringol. Herein, we have synthesized an in–situ activated cobalt–silver bimetallic catalyst, CoAg/SiO2, through a simple incipient–wetness impregnation method. The catalyst without pre–reduction treatment attained a complete conversion with 93.8 mol% CYHAOL selectivity under moderate reaction conditions. Characterizations including HRTEM, XPS, XRD, NH3–TPD, and H2–TPR unanimously revealed the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst. In the reaction system, Ag promoted the in–situ reduction of Co3O4 to form a polycrystalline–structure complex (CoOx) containing oxygen vacancies. Ag also combines with Co to construct strong acid sites. The synergy of CoOx, oxygen vacancies, Ag, and acid sites demonstrates a high–efficiency HDO of syringol to CYHAOL. CoAg/SiO2 exonerates the pre–reduction treatment, simplifying the preparation and maintenance process and preventing severe sintering of the metals. Graphical Abstract Ag not only promotes Co3O4 to in-situ reduction into a polycrystalline-structure complex (CoOx) with oxygen vacancies but also combines with Co to construct strong acid site in the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst, which demonstrates a high-efficiency hydrodeoxygenation of syringol to cyclohexanol. Keywords CoAg bimetallic catalyst In situ activation Hydrodeoxygenation Syringol Cyclohexanol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the accelerated consumption of conventional fossil fuels leads to insufficient resources of petroleum–based fuels and increasingly severe environmental pollution, lignocellulosic biomass has been widely developed as an alternative for fossil fuels in the synthesis of biofuels and bio–based chemical reagents [1]. For instance, lignin can be degraded into syringols, guaiacols, and phenols, which have great potential as feedstocks for bulk–platform chemicals with C6 ring, such as phenol (Ph), cyclohexanol (CYHAOL) and cyclohexane（CYHA). Typically, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is universally recognized as an effective strategy to drive the relevant chemical reactions [2,3]. The catalytic reaction chemistry for HDO of lignin can be well understood by using lignin–derived compounds like syringol, guaiacol (GUA), and Ph in the fundament researches [4]. Syringol contains two methoxy groups and a phenolic hydroxyl group, which represents a relatively complicated representative unit of lignin [5,6]. Therefore, using syringol as the model compound means facing a higher challenge in developing efficient catalysts for HDO of lignin. In past decades, systematic studies on HDO of syringol have been minimal, while most works have used GUA and Ph as model compounds [2,3,7]. Noble metal catalysts such as Ru and Pd–based catalysts [8–11] have been employed for the HDO of syringol, and at the same time, transition metal catalysts like Ni [6] and Co–based [12,13] catalysts have been used for the HDO reaction. Feng et al. [9] compared the reaction characteristics of the three lignin model compounds over the Ru/SBA-15 catalyst and found that after 4 h reaction under 80 °C and 2 MPa hydrogen pressure，the selectivity to CYHAOL were 10.8 %, 25.2 % and 99.9 % to syringol, guaiacol and phenol, respectively. Zhao et al. [11] also conducted a comparative study on the HDO of the three model compounds over Pd/C and HZSM-5 combined catalysts and found that the HDO of syringyol was much more complicated than the others. Therefore, catalysts with high activity in the HDO reactions of guaiacol and phenol cannot predict the same activities in the syringol reaction. Ni/SiO2–Al2O3 transition metal catalyst has been used to catalyze the HDO of syringol [6]. After the 2 h reaction at 200 °C and 2 MPa hydrogen pressure, the conversion reaches 98.4 %, and CYHA accounts for 97.8 % of the total product. Liu et al. [13] reported a magnetic nitrogen–doped carbon–supported cobalt catalyst (CoNx@NC) for HDO of syringol at 200 °C and 2 MPa hydrogen pressure and found that all syringol converted to CYHA after a 12 h reaction. Admittedly, the HDO reaction of syringol readily produces CYHA rather than staying in the intermediate product like CYHAOL. Moreover, some studies demonstrated that syringol is more prone to coke deposition than phenol and guaiacol [14]. Therefore, syringol with intricate molecular structure significantly complicates the HDO reaction as compared to GUA and Ph. The considerable steric hindrance and multiple reaction functional groups of syringol stagnate the reaction efficiency, make the intermediate product selectivity unmanageable, and induce carbon accumulation. To address these problems, efficient catalysts must be developed with good activity and high selectivity. In the present work, we developed a cobalt−silver bimetallic catalyst supported on silica (CoAg/SiO2) through the simple incipient–wetness impregnation method and employed it for HDO of syringol with high selectivity to CYHAOL. Unlike the traditional Co–based catalysts that rely on the pre–reduction treatment to generate the metallic Co for hydrogenation reactions, the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst does not need pre–reduction treatment and can be in situ activated in the reaction system with Ag promotion. Moreover, the Co–active species of CoAg/SiO2 are predominately in Co oxides rather than in metallic Co. To our knowledge, this is the rarely mentioned CoAg–based catalyst that can exhibit good HDO activity for biomass upgradation without pre–reduction treatment. In combination with characteristic studies including transmission electron microscope (TEM), X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X–ray diffraction (XRD), NH3–temperature–programmed desorption (NH3–TPD), H2–temperature–programmed reduction (H2–TPR) and N2 physical adsorption at low temperature, the preparation condition of the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst and the reaction process were optimized, and the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst was analyzed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Take CoAg/SiO2 catalyst as an example. Co(NO3)2•6 H2O and AgNO3 were used as Co and Ag providers. The salts were supported on SiO2 by the incipient wetness impregnation method. After impregnation, the catalyst precursor was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in air. For comparative study, Co/SiO2 and Ag/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized using the same method as that of CoAg/SiO2. Co3O4 powder was prepared by precipitation method with 0.1 mol/L NaOH solution titrated into Co(NO3)2 solution. The catalysts in this study were designated as CoxAgy/SiO2, where x and y were the amount (mmol) of Co and Ag supported per gram of the supporter. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high–resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images were analyzed with Tecnai G2 F30 microscope. The catalyst was ultrasonic treated in ethanol, then deposited on the copper grides. X–ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by Rigaku Smart Lab X–ray diffractometer. The radiation source was Cu–Kα ray (λ=1.5406 A). X ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) was recorded on ESCALAB–250 (Al Kα monochromatic X–ray source with E=1486.6 eV and 50 eV pass energy). The peak position was corrected with C1s (284.6 eV), and the spectral images were analyzed with XPSPEAK 41 program. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test was performed using AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. For each test, 20 mg of the sample was dried in Ar at 300 °C and reduced in 5 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture (40 mL/min) at a linear heating rate of 10 °C/min from 50 °C to 700 °C. H2 consumption was monitored by TCD detector. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was also tested over the AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. For each test, 40 mg of the sample was dried in Ar at 300 °C, saturated with NH3 at 100 °C, and then desorbed in a stream of He (40 mL/min) at a linear heating rate of 10 °C/min from 100 °C to 700 °C. The desorbed NH3 was monitored by TCD detector. Surface area characterization of the catalysts was performed with Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The specific surface area (S BET) was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation (P/P0=0.05–0.3). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the fresh and spent catalysts was performed on the TGA/SDTA851e analyzer at a rate of 10 °C/min and an airflow rate of 30 mL/min. 2.3 Catalysts testing The HDO reactions of syringol were carried out in an autocontrol batch reactor (50 mL; Beijing Century Senlang Experimental Apparatus Co. Ltd.). The typical reaction process is as follows. Firstly, 500 mg of syringol, 50 mg of catalyst, 10 mL of n-dodecane, and 100 mg of tetradecane as internal standard were sealed to the reactor. After checking the gas tightness, the reactor was pressurized with H2 to 3.0 MPa at room temperature, heated to the target temperature, and reacted for a specific time. After the reaction, the liquid product was analyzed by Agilent 7820 gas chromatography with a SE–30 capillary column (Dalian Zhonghuida Scientific Instrument Co., Ltd, China) and a flame ionization detector. The spent catalyst was recovered by centrifugal separation and vacuum drying for characterization or repeated tests. The conversion of syringol, the yield and selectivity of the product in molar percentage were quantified based on the number of C6 rings in the substrate. The carbon balance of the products was within the range of experimental error (±3%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CoAg/SiO2 catalyst 3.1.1 Electron microscope images Fig. 1 shows TEM and HRTEM images of the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst before and after the reaction. The weight percent loading of Co and Ag in the catalyst is 9.7 wt% and 4.4 wt%, respectively. The CoAg nanoparticles in the fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst are homogeneously dispersed on the surface of SiO2, with an average particle size of 3 nm. The typical lattice fringe of the nanoparticles at around 0.243 nm is attributed to the (311) crystal plane of Co3O4 (JCPDS PDF Card No.:76–1802). The slightly larger size (0.244 nm) may be due to incorporating Ag atoms with larger atomic radius into the nanoparticles, leading to the slight expansion and increase of the lattice spacing of Co3O4 [15]. No Ag–related lattice fringes were observed in TEM images, indicating that Ag atoms were highly dispersed after impregnation and calcination. The TEM image of the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst in Fig. 1(c) shows that the average particle size of metal nanoparticles increases to 4 nm, indicating the slight sintering of the nanoparticles during the reaction. As shown in Fig. 1(d), the nanoparticles in the spent catalyst show lattice fringes with different sizes ranging from 0.210 nm to 0.250 nm. The lattice fringe of Co (111) is 0.205 nm (JCPDS PDF Card No.:15–0806), the lattice fringes of CoO (200) and CoO (111) are 0.213 nm and 0.246 nm (JCPDS PDF Card No.:48–1719), respectively, and the fringes of Co2O3 (102) and Co2O3 (002) are 0.233 nm and 0.287 nm (JCPDS PDF Card No.:02–0770), respectively. Due to the in–situ reduction of Co oxides in Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst during the reaction, the compositions of the nanoparticles no longer belong to Co3O4 but change into a variety of crystalline structures with diversified lattice fringes. The lattice fringe of 0.210 nm is presumed to be the (111) plane of Co derived from the incomplete reduction of CoO. The lattice fringes of 0.212 nm and 0.215 nm are assumed to be the CoO (200) plane, and the lattice fringes of 0.239 nm and 0.250 nm are likely to correspond to the Co2O3. Because the Co, CoO, and Co2O3 crystals were partly reduced and incorporated with Ag atoms, the lattice fringes in Fig. 1d cannot precisely correspond to the standard values in the JCPDS PDF Cards. Therefore, the TEM characterization results showed that original Co3O4 nanoparticles in the fresh catalyst were in–situ reduced into Co, CoO and Co2O3 incorporated with Ag atoms in the reaction system. Such compositions are imperfect crystals with high entropy and tend to construct lattice defects, such as oxygen vacancies [16]. The Co–oxide component in the spent catalyst was denoted as CoOx in this study. The lattice fringes corresponding to metallic Ag can be occasionally found in some HRTEM images of the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. S1. 3.1.2 XPS Fig. 2 shows the XPS spectra of fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts. With the increase of the valence state, the binding energy of most metals shifts to a higher level, but Co and Ag are exceptions. The 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spin–orbital splitting peaks of Co0 are near 778.4 eV and 793.4 eV, respectively [17]. The peaks of Co2+ are around 782.1 eV and 798.0 eV, respectively, accompanied by the satellite peaks at 787.9 eV and 803.6 eV [18]. The 2p binding energy of Co3+ is between that of Co0 and Co2+. The Co3+ is characterized by the Co 2p3/2 peak at 780.3 eV and Co 2p1/2 peak at 795.3 eV, with an energy difference of 15 eV [18]. As for Ag, the higher the valence state of Ag, the lower the binding energy. The spin–orbital splitting peaks of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Ag0 are around 368.0–368.3 eV and 374.0–374.3 eV, respectively, while those of Ag+ and Ag2+ are 0.3 eV and 0.7 eV lower than that of Ag0 [19]. In Fig. 2(a), it is found that the Co energy spectrum of fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst exhibits two chemical states of Co2+ and Co3+ according to the peak–splitting fitting result. After the reaction, the Co components in the spent catalyst also contained Co2+ and Co3+, and Co0, if any, is not evident. The ratio of the peak area of Co2+ to Co3+ in the fresh catalyst is about 0.5:1, and that of the spent catalyst is about 0.9:1. The increase in the proportion of Co2+ indicates that high–valence Co is partially reduced to low–valence Co in the reaction system, which is consistent with the results inferred from the lattice fringes in HRTEM in Fig. 1(d). As shown in Fig. 2(b), the Ag 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks of the fresh catalyst are mainly assigned to the binding energy of Ag0 and a tiny amount of Ag+, and the peaks of the spent catalyst are only assigned to Ag0. The results indicate that Ag exists mainly in the form of metallic Ag0 in the fresh catalyst after calcinating at 500 °C, and the small amount remaining Ag+ is completely reduced to Ag0 under the reaction condition. The O 1 s spectra of the fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2c. The O 1 s spectra of SiO2 are too strong so they have covered up the signal of O relating to CoOx. We used a sample (Co3O4-H2) to simulate “CoOx”, which was prepared by reduction of Co3O4 with 5 v.% H2 in Ar at 350 °C. The Co 2p spectrum of Co3O4-H2 in Fig. S2 indicates that the Co0, Co2+, and Co3+ species are simultaneously present in the sample, just similar to CoOx in the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst. The O 1 s spectrum of Co3O4-H2 splits into three overlapping peaks. In addition to the peaks relating to the O1 bonded to Co oxides and O3 adsorbed on Co3O4-H2, the O2 peak at around 531.2 eV is associated with the O atoms in the vicinity of oxygen vacancies [20], predicting that there are abundant oxygen vacancies in CoOx. The element contents on the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 surface are summarized in Table S1 of Supplementary Information. The atomic percentage of Co changes little after the reaction, manifesting the stability of the supported Co species under reaction conditions. The atomic percentage of Ag decreases from 0.45 at% to 0.37 at% after the reaction, indicating that Ag sinters to some extent. 3.1.3 XRD The XRD patterns in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3 show that the Co components of the fresh and spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts are much different. The SiO2 (101) crystal plane diffraction peak near 2θ=22° (JCPDS PDF Card No.: 39–1425) exists in all four samples. The XRD pattern of Co2.0/SiO2 can be classified as the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 (JCPDS PDF Card No.:76–1802), with the strongest signal of Co3O4 (311) crystal phase at 2θ=36.9°. The diffraction signal of the fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst is similar to that of Co2.0/SiO2 catalyst. No diffraction peak related to Ag is found in Ag/SiO2 and fresh Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts, indicating that Ag is highly dispersed on the surface of SiO2. The XRD pattern of the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst shows that the diffraction signal of Co3O4 almost disappears, indicating that Co3O4 in the fresh catalyst is no longer the main component of nanoparticles in the spent catalyst. According to the lattice fringes of HRTEM in Fig. 1(d), it is speculated that the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst contains complex of Co, CoO and Co2O3 (CoOx). The Co substances with different valence states and imperfect crystals are doped with each other, weakening the crystallinity so that the XRD diffraction signal is not obvious. This result confirms the in–situ reduction of Co3O4 nanoparticles of the catalyst in the reaction system. The weak diffraction peaks of metallic Ag appear in the XRD pattern of the spent catalyst, indicating that Ag slightly aggregates into nanoparticles after the reaction, consistent with the XPS results. 3.1.4 H2–TPR The H2–TPR pattern of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 is shown in Fig. 4, and the patterns of Co2.0/SiO2 and Ag0.5/SiO2 are also listed for comparison. Generally, the reduction process of Co3O4 can be divided into two steps: reduction of Co3O4 to CoO followed by the reduction reaction of CoO to Co [21]. The multipeak of Co2.0/SiO2 corresponds to the two–step reduction of Co oxides around 410 °C and 600 °C, respectively. The H2–TPR pattern of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 is similar to that of Co2.0/SiO2, except that the two peaks move to lower temperatures by about 100 °C, indicating that Ag lowers the reduction temperature of Co oxides in Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2. The function of Ag in promoting the reduction of metal oxides has been reported [15,22,23]. For example, the reduction temperature of Cu decreases from 259 °C to 126 °C after the addition of Ag into Cu/Al2O3 catalyst [15]. That Ag significantly lowered the reduction temperature of metal oxides is attributed to the spillover H originated from Ag dissociation of molecular H2 [23]. In the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst, reduction of Co oxides becomes easy due to the promotion of Ag, which is conducive to the in-situ reduction of Co oxides in the catalyst under reaction conditions. This speculation is consistent with the results of HRTEM and XRD that almost no Co3O4 was presented in the spent catalyst, which was replaced by a polycrystalline–structure complex of CoO and Co2O3 with more share of Co2+. Ag mainly exists in metallic Ag in the catalysts, which is the reason that the reduction peak of Ag2O is not obvious in the H2–TPR patterns. In short, the metallic Ag promotes the in-situ reduction of Co oxides, which will have an important influence on the catalytic function. 3.1.5 NH3–TPD The results of the NH3–TPD tests on SiO2, Ag-based, and Co-based catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5. The NH3–TPD profile of γ-Al2O3 was tested in the same conditions as the others for acidity reference, which was shown in Fig. S4 of Supplementary Information. Compared with that of γ-Al2O3, the acid amounts of the SiO2, Ag-based, and Co-based catalysts are much lower. For example, the acid amount of SiO2 is less than a tenth of γ-Al2O3. SiO2 is mainly included in the NH3 desorption peak centered around 200 °C, indicating that the support has a certain number of weak acid sites (NH3 desorbed at T < 300 °C). The NH3–TPD patterns of Ag0.5/SiO2 and Co2.0/SiO2 contain broad peats centered around 400 °C and 450 °C, respectively, in addition to the low-temperature peaks as SiO2 has, manifesting that the metal species bring a few strong acid sites (NH3 desorbed at T > 300 °C) to the catalysts. The NH3–TPD profile of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 contains a low-temperature peak and an overlap high-temperature peak crossed from 350 °C to 550 °C. Fig. S4 shows that the reduction of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 at 260 °C (same as the reaction temperature) with H2 (Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2-H2) weakens the stronger acid peak around 460 °C, but the catalyst still reserves a certain number of strong acid sites centered around 400 °C. Thus, Ag and Co contribute to the creation of new strong acid sites, which is similar to the report [24] that Ag and Fe bring new strong acid sites to the ZrO2 support. 3.1.6 N2 adsorption/desorption Fig. S5 shows the adsorption/desorption isotherms of N2 on SiO2 and the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst at the temperature controlled by liquid nitrogen. Both SiO2 and Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 present typical–Ⅳ isotherms with steep H1–type hysteretic rings at a relative pressure of 0.8 < p/p°<1.0, indicating the mesoporous nature of the samples with a uniform pore size distribution. The specific surface area of the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst is 154 m2·g−1, and the pore volume is 0.53 cm3·g−1, slightly lowering than that of SiO2. 3.2 Function analysis of the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst Data in entries 1–6 of Table 1 describe the catalytic properties of the catalysts containing Co, Ag, and SiO2 components in whole or in part. All the catalysts were calcinated in air and then used in HDO of syringol, without pre-reduction treatment. CYHAOL is the main product, and GUA, Ph and CYHA are the typical byproducts. The products labeled as “Others” mainly refer to unlisted and unidentified product mixtures, including the products of methyl transfer of intermediates and partial hydrogenation of aromatic ring. The Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst completes the conversion of syringol at the reaction condition of 260 °C and 3.0 MPa H2 for 2 h, and the selectivity to CYHAOL reaches 93.8 mol%, showing high catalytic activity and good selectivity. The Co2.0/SiO2 catalyst converts 12.0 mol% of syringol with only 3.4 mol% yield of CYHAOL, and Ag0.5/SiO2 shows no activity in the reaction. The conversion of syringol over the physical mixture of Co2.0/SiO2 and Ag0.5/SiO2 is only 11.5 mol%, far less than that over the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst. SiO2 itself has no catalytic activity in this reaction. Comparison of the abovementioned reaction results manifests that the good catalytic performance of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 depends on the synergy of Co and Ag. The conversion of syringol to CYHAOL involves the functions of hydrogenation of the benzene ring and hydrolysis of the C–OCH3 bond. Ag has been used as an active component for hydrogenation reactions [25], but it showed poor hydrogenation capability on the aromatic ring even if catalyzed at 300 °C and 3 MPa H2 [23]. In this reaction, syringol is almost unconverted over Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst (entry 3, Table 1), so the bifunction is unlikely provided by Ag and the weak acidic SiO2. Generally, metallic Co is a key element for the Co–based catalyst to generate hydrogenation performance. Good evidence is that Co3O4 has no catalytic activity (entry 6, Table 1) while the catalytic activity of Co3O4–H2 was significantly improved after the pre–reduction of Co3O4 with hydrogen at 350 °C (entry 7, Table 1). This result is consistent with the trend observed in the literature that Co–based catalysts [22,26,27], including CoAg–based catalysts [22], were generally pre–treated with a reduction of Co oxides before catalyzing the reaction. However, the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst was calcined in air at 500 °C and used without hydrogen pre–reduction treatment but showed excellent catalytic performance in HDO of syringol. As evidenced by the abovementioned characterization results of the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst, Ag not only facilitates the in-situ reduction of Co3O4 to form CoOx polycrystalline in the reaction system but also combines with Co to construct stronger acid sites. Strong acid strength and high–concentration acid sites can engender enhanced deoxygenation activities [28]. Moreover, partial reduction enhances the defective structure of the CoO and Co2O3 phases, creating oxygen vacancies on the CoOx surface [29,30]. Such surface oxygen vacancy sites have been proven to be conducive to the adsorption and activation of oxygen–containing functional groups of phenolic compounds [30]. A recent study reported that CoO incorporating oxygen vacancies constructed the catalytically active sites to drive the heterolytic and homolytic cleavage of H2 to yield more active Hδ− species, resulting in the exceptional catalytic activity in the HDO of lignin model compounds [31]. Yang et al. [32] also reported a Co-oxide-based catalyst for HDO reaction. Evidently, as shown in Fig. 6, the excellent catalytic activity of the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst in the HDO of syringol was attributable to the as–fabricated components of the catalyst. Ag promotes the in-situ reduction of Co3O4 under reaction conditions, fabricating the CoOx polycrystalline with oxygen vacancies (Ov). Ag and CoOx–Ov sites are responsible for the activation of H2, supplying active H atoms for hydrogenation and hydrolysis. The stronger acid sites and the oxygen vacancies in CoOx play roles in activating the aromatic ring and C–O bonds. The synergistic effect of these components completes the catalytic function of hydrogenation of benzene ring and hydrolysis of C–OCH3 bond so that syringol can be efficiently converted to CYHAOL. Ag promotes Co3O4 in situ reduction, which is why the catalyst can show excellent catalytic performance without pre-reduction treatment. The Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst exonerates the pre-reduction treatment, which not only simplifies the preparation and maintenance of the catalyst, but also avoids the deactivation of the catalyst due to the oxidation of the active metals [33,34]. 3.3 Effect of catalyst preparation condition 3.3.1 Effect of metal composition Table 2 shows the catalytic results of CoAg/SiO2 catalysts with different Co and Ag loadings in HDO of syringol at conditions of 5 wt% catalyst loading (with respect to syringol mass) and 0.5 h reaction. All catalysts were calcined in air and used for reaction without pre-reduction treatment. Monometallic Co2.0/SiO2 obtained very low conversion and monometallic Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst has no activity. When 0.2 mmol/g Ag is added to Co2.0/SiO2, the conversion of syringol over Co2.0Ag0.2/SiO2 increases significantly to 23.7 mol% at 5 wt% catalyst loading and 0.5 h reaction, indicating the vital role of Ag in mediating the catalytic function. The syringol conversion and the yield of CYHAOL first increase and then decrease with the increase of the Ag loadings from 0.2 mmol/g to 1.0 mmol/g, and the maximum values are achieved at 0.5 mmol/g of the Ag loading. Reaction over the catalyst with 1.0 mmol/g Ag loadings only receives 18.3 mol% conversion, which indicates that too much Ag not only contributes little to the activity but also increases the cost of the catalyst. The effect of Co loading on the catalyst performance was investigated with the Ag loading fixed at 0.5 mmol/g. The syringol conversion and the yield of CYHAOL increase with the increase of the Co loadings from 1.0 mmol/g to 3.0 mmol/g, which means that it is possible to obtain a catalyst superior to the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst by optimizing the Co loading. Fig. 7 shows the XRD results of CoAg/SiO2 catalysts with different Ag and Co loadings. The XRD patterns of all samples mainly include the diffraction signals of SiO2 (JCPDS PDF Card No.:39–1425) and Co3O4 (JCPDS Card No.:76–1802). Fig. 7a shows that no Ag diffraction signal was found in the XRD diffraction pattern of the catalysts with different Ag loadings even when the Ag loading was 1.0 mmol/g. At the same time, the diffraction peak intensity of Co3O4 decreases slightly with the increase of Ag content, accompanied by the left shift of the 2-theta angles with the increase of Ag content, indicating that the Ag component dispersed into the Co3O4 crystal to a certain extent. Fig. 7b shows that the diffraction peak intensity of Co3O4 increases slightly with the increase of Co content from 1.0 mmol/g to 3.0 mmol/g, manifesting that a high Co loading of 3.0 mmol/g can still disperse well on the SiO2 surface, contributing more active sites to the reactants. According to the reaction and characteristic results, a lower Ag loading of 0.5 mmol/g is preferred, and appropriately increasing the Co loading, such as 3 mmol of Co per g of SiO2, can further improve the catalyst activity. 3.3.2 Effect of catalyst calcination temperature The Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst is prepared with no pre-reduction treatment before use, so calcinating in the air is an essential last procedure. Table S2 shows the performance of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts at different calcination temperatures in HDO of syringol. The conversion of syringol and the yield of CYHAOL first increase and then decrease along with the increase in the calcination temperature from 400 °C to 700 °C, with the optimal results occurring at the calcination temperature of 500 °C. Fig. 8 shows XRD patterns of Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. The diffraction peaks of Co3O4 crystals in the catalysts change little, but those of Ag change evidently with the increase of calcination temperature. The diffraction peaks of Ag do not appear in the samples calcined at 400–500 °C but are present in the sample calcined at temperatures above 500 °C, especially at 700 °C (JCPDS PDF Card No.:87–0597), indicating that high calcination temperatures tend to leach and aggregate the Ag components, which is the main reason for the poor catalytic performance of the catalysts calcined at 600–700 °C. Considering the catalytic activity and the yield of CYHAOL, 500 °C is the best calcination temperature for Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst. 3.4 Effects of reaction conditions The influences of reaction conditions, including temperature, time, and H2 pressure, on the HDO reaction of syringol were investigated using the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst calcined at 500 °C, and the results are summarized in Fig. 9. Fig. 9a shows that HDO of syringol is highly temperature dependent. The syringol conversion increases with increasing reaction temperature and reaches complete conversion at 260 °C. In addition, the reaction temperature also drastically affects the product distribution. At lower temperatures at 220–240 °C, GUA and Ph appear in the products in inescapable proportion, and the CYHAOL selectivity was no more than 60 mol%. With the reaction temperature increased, the GUA and Ph selectivity decreases gradually while the CYHAOL selectivity increases and achieves the maximum yield of 93.9 mol% at 260 °C. As the temperature increases, the CYHAOL selectivity decreases gradually, accompanied by the increase of the CYHA selectivity. Especially, a higher temperature of 300 °C is conducive to cleavage of Calkyl−OH, promoting formation of CYHA. The products of partial hydrogenation of benzene ring and methyl transfer of syringol and intermediates, which are termed as “Others”, can eventually transformed into the target product CYHAOL with the progress of the reaction. The influence of reaction time (Fig. 9b) and H2 pressure (Fig. 9c) on the conversion of syringol and the distribution of products over the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst are similar to that of the reaction temperature. Generally, the yield of CYHAOL increases at the initial stage of the reaction conditions and then decreases gradually as the conditions extend. Combined with the research results in Fig. 9, it can be concluded that the HDO of syringol over Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 is related to complex thermodynamics and kinetics problems. The high CYHAOL yield over 90 mol% can be obtained by optimizing the reaction conditions according to the kinetic thermodynamic characteristics. 3.5 Stability test of catalyst Fig. 10 shows the recyclability of the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst in the hydrodeoxygenation of syringol into CYHAOL. After the reaction, the catalyst was centrifugally separated, washed with ethyl acetate, vacuum–dried, and directly used in the next test with the same conditions for each repetition. As can be seen from Fig. 9, the conversion of syringol over the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst decreased from 100 mol% in the first test to 98.8 mol% in the third test, and the selectivity of CYHAOL decreased from 93.8 mol% to 86.7 mol%, indicating the slight deactivation of the catalyst in three repeated use. In general, catalyst deactivation is associated with metal sintering [33,34] and carbon deposition [6,35]. The TEM image (Fig. 1c and d) and the XRD pattern (Fig. 3) of the spent catalyst manifested that the metal sintering was not evident after the reaction. The supports may affect the catalytic properties of metal sites [36–38], acid sites [39,40], metal–support interaction [41,42]. Some supports such as Al2O3-HZSM-5 have stronger chemical interaction between metal and supports, which prevent easy migration of metal particles by maintaining the metal species in metal cations [40]. SiO2 used in this study is an inert support that is prone to form weak metal-support interaction [36,41–43]. However, the metal species didn’t sinter severely in the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst. This is because the catalyst requires no H2 pre-reduction treatment. Zhang et al. reported that the metal sintering of the in situ reduced CuAg/Al2O3 was much weaker than that of the one reduced in the H2 stream [15]. Promoted by Ag, the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst was reduced in situ during the reaction, and the reduced Co species were not pure metallic Co but a mixture of valence states, that is, containing Co cations, which leads to very slight sintering of the metals. Fig. S4 shows the TG analysis results of fresh and used Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst in air. Weight loss between 50–200 °C is caused by the evaporation of residual moisture in the catalyst. The slight increase of the weight around 250 °C in the spent Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst is attributed to the oxidation of the Co species from low valence states to high valence states, which is another evidence of Ag promoting the in situ reduction of Co oxides during reaction. The weight of the fresh catalyst tends to be constant after 300 °C. In contrast, the mass of the spent catalyst dropped sharply between 300 and 600 °C, indicating that carbon deposition occurred in the catalyst during the reaction process. According to the percentage variation range, carbon deposition material was equivalent to 2.2 wt% of the mass of the catalyst, which accounts for 0.22 wt% of the raw material. Based on the above analysis, coking is the main reason for the deactivation. 3.6 Proposed reaction pathways Results in Fig. 9 show that in the initial stage of the reaction, evident GUA and Ph are generated. As the reaction constantly proceeds, the selectivities to GUA and Ph gradually decrease, while CYHAOL gradually increases. The selectivity to CYHA increases slowly. The probe reactions were carried out over the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst with GUA, Ph, CYHAOL and CYHA as raw materials, and the results are shown in Table 3. The reactions contained equimolar quantities of raw materials with respected to 500 mg of syringol. Syringol is completely converted under 260 °C and 3.0 MPa H2 pressure for 2 h. If GUA is the only intermediate in converting syringol to CYHAOL, it must be completely converted since syringol has been completely converted. However, the conversion of GUA is only 83.3 mol% with Ph and CYHAOL as the main products. This suggests that other pathways to CYHAOL do not go through GUA. It has been mentioned in the literature that syringol can simultaneously dissociate methoxy to produce Ph [44], which constructs another reaction path to produce CYHAOL. Ph conversion over Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 reaches 100 mol%, with a primary product of CYHAOL and a small amount of CYHA, so the reaction from Ph to CYHAOL is easy to carry out. For CYHAOL and CYHA, only 5.9 mol% of CYHAOL is converted, and CYHA almost does not transform on the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that they are relatively stable in the Co2.0Ag0.5/SiO2 catalyzed reaction system. Cobalt catalysts have been reported to promote the alkylation and hydrogenolysis reactions of aromatic compounds [45]. When using syringol and GUA as feeds, methane and methanol can be detected in the liquid and gas products. When using phenol, CYHAOL, and CYHA as feeds, no methane and methanol occurred. Thus, we speculated that methane and methanol come not from hexatonic rings but from the dissociated methoxy groups of syringol and the intermediates containing methoxy groups. Based on the rule of product change and the above probe reaction results, reaction pathways of HDO of syringol over the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst are proposed. As shown in Scheme 1, syringol removes the C–OCH3 bonds one by one, thus causing the formation of GUA and Ph. The methoxy groups may also be hydro-dissociated in the form of CH4 and H2O. Ph can be converted into CYHAOL through ring hydrogenation. Further, the cleavage of the Caryl–OH group in CYHAOL can produce CYHA. Syringol is also susceptible to the simultaneous cleavage of the two methoxy groups from syringyl to produce Ph. In addition to the above reactions, the hydrogenation of benzene rings of GUA forms trace amounts of 2-methoxycyclohexanol, a byproduct that can be transformed into CYHAOL through demethoxylation. Cleavage of the Caryl–OH bond relies on the strong bronsted acidity that can be provided by H+ acid supports such as HZSM-5 zeolite [46,47]. In the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst, the Lewis acid of CoOx [48] appropriately avoids to cleave the Caryl–OH bond, which potentially makes the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst have good selectivity to CYHAOL. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have synthesized an in situ activated CoAg/SiO2 catalyst through a simple incipient–wetness impregnation method and implemented it for the HDO of syringol to CYHAOL with high selectivity. The Co–based catalysts, including CoAg–based catalysts, in the literature generally underwent pre-reduction treatment of Co oxides to metallic Co before catalyzing the hydrogenation reaction. However, the as-synthesized CoAg/SiO2 catalyst was calcined in air at 500 °C and used without hydrogen pre-reduction treatment, attaining a complete conversion with 93.8 mol% CYHAOL selectivity under comparatively moderate reaction conditions at 260 °C, 3.0 MPa hydrogen pressure and 2 h. The structure–activity relationship of the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst has been illustrated through a combination of experiments and a wide range of characterizations. The H2–TPR study revealed that Ag can lower the reduction temperature of Co3O4 on the SiO2 surface. The HRTEM, XPS, and XRD results unanimously evidenced that promoted by Ag, Co3O4 originally in the fresh catalyst is in-situ reduced in the reaction system and turned into a polycrystalline–structure complex with the partly reduced CoO and Co2O3 phases, named CoOx, which contained the lattice defects and oxygen vacancies. Moreover, NH3–TPD result revealed that Ag and Co contribute to the creation of new strong acid sites in the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst. Ag and CoOx with oxygen vacancies (CoOx–Ov) cleavage the H2 molecule, and at the same time, the strong acid sites and the oxygen vacancies in CoOx activate the aromatic ring and C–OCH3 bonds. The synergistic effect of these components completes the catalytic function of hydrogenation of the benzene ring and hydrolysis of C–OCH3 bonds so that syringol can be efficiently converted into CYHAOL. The CoAg/SiO2 catalyst exonerates the pre-reduction treatment, which not only simplifies the preparation and maintenance of the catalyst but also avoids the deactivation of the catalyst due to the oxidation of the active metals and severe sintering, providing a significant reference in the catalyst–contraction technologies. coredata.dc:description: Development of highly effective catalysts for selective hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of syringol, a model compound of lignin, to cyclohexanol (CYHAOL) is a challenge due to the intricate molecular structure of syringol. Herein, we have synthesized an in–situ activated cobalt–silver bimetallic catalyst, CoAg/SiO2, through a simple incipient–wetness impregnation method. The catalyst without pre–reduction treatment attained a complete conversion with 93.8 mol% CYHAOL selectivity under moderate reaction conditions. Characterizations including HRTEM, XPS, XRD, NH3–TPD, and H2–TPR unanimously revealed the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst. In the reaction system, Ag promoted the in–situ reduction of Co3O4 to form a polycrystalline–structure complex (CoOx) containing oxygen vacancies. Ag also combines with Co to construct strong acid sites. The synergy of CoOx, oxygen vacancies, Ag, and acid sites demonstrates a high–efficiency HDO of syringol to CYHAOL. CoAg/SiO2 exonerates the pre–reduction treatment, simplifying the preparation and maintenance process and preventing severe sintering of the metals.
coredata.dc:title: In situ activated CoAg bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrodeoxygenation of syringol to cyclohexanol
